nodes.text: The Interest Tax Deduction and Firm Value
, corporations can deduct interest expenses from their taxable income.

Starting in 2018, firms with more than $25 million in revenue cannot deduct interest exceeding 30% of their earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA). After 2021, this limit drops to 30% of EBIT instead of EBITDA.
The deduction reduces the taxes they pay and thereby increases the amount available to pay investors. In doing so, the interest tax deduction increases the value of the corporation.

To illustrate, let’s consider the impact of interest expenses on the taxes paid by The Kroger Co., a grocery store chain. In 2018, Kroger had earnings before interest and taxes of $4.60 billion, and interest expenses of $620 million. Given a corporate tax rate of 21%, we can compare Kroger’s actual net income with what it would have been without debt, as shown in

config.activityTitle: Kroger’s Income with and Without Leverage, 2018 ($ million)

nodes.text: , Kroger’s net income in 2018 was lower with leverage than it would have been without leverage. Thus, Kroger’s debt obligations reduced the value of its equity. But more importantly, the
With leverage, Kroger was able to pay out $3764 million in total to its investors, versus only $3634 million without leverage, representing an increase of $130 million.
It might seem odd that a firm can be better off with leverage even though its earnings are lower. But recall from

that the value of a firm is the total amount it can raise from all investors, not just equity holders who receive the earnings. Thus, if the firm can pay out more in total with leverage, it will be able to raise more total capital initially.
Where does the additional $130 million come from? Looking at
, we can see that this gain is equal to the reduction in taxes with leverage:

nodes.text: In general, the gain to investors from the tax deductibility of interest payments is referred to as the
The reduction in taxes paid due to the tax deductibility of interest payments.

. The interest tax shield is the additional amount a firm can pay to investors by saving the taxes it would have paid if it did not have leverage. We can calculate the amount of the interest tax shield each year as follows:

data.mathML: <math display="block"><mrow><mtext>Interest Tax Shield</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>Corporate Tax Rate</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>Interest Payments</mtext></mrow></math>
data.alt: Interest Tax Shield equals Corporate Tax Rate times Interest Payments

nodes.text: Example 16.3 Computing the Interest Tax Shield

Shown below is the pro-forma forecasted income statement for E. C. Builders (ECB). Given its marginal corporate tax rate of 25%, what is the amount of the interest tax shield for ECB in years 2020 through 2023?
, the interest tax shield is the tax rate of 25% multiplied by the interest payments in each year.

By using debt, ECB is able to reduce its taxable income and therefore decrease its total tax payments by $82.5 million over the four-year period. Thus, the total amount of cash flows available to all investors (debt holders and equity holders) is $82.5 million higher over the four-year period.
